article.text: The UN Security Council called on Syrian president Bashar al-Assad to keep his commitment to stop using heavy weapons against the Syrian opposition and to withdraw his forces from cities by April 10. As the Assad regime continued attacks in civilian areas, the Council adopted a presidential statement today calling on Syria to “urgently and visibly” withdraw forces from population centers. It asked all groups to cease armed violence within 48 hours of Syrian government implementation of its The Council reaffirmed its support for special envoy Kofi Annan and his six-point proposal “aimed at bringing an immediate end to all violence and human rights violations, securing humanitarian access and facilitating a Syrian-led political transition leading to a democratic, plural political The statement also urged access be permitted for humanitarian-aid workers and implementation of a UN monitoring mission. The UN’s policy-making body, which has been unable to reach agreement with Russia and China on a binding Syria resolution, said it will “consider further steps as Clashes took place today in the central cities of Homs and Hama, the northern governorate of Idlib and the Damascus suburb of Douma, in which 27 people were killed, including three children, the Local Coordination Committees said in an e-mail. “We are not aware of any signs of military withdrawal till this moment,” said Rami Abdel Rahman, head of the U.K.-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, in a phone interview.“The shelling and violence is as normal.” UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon, addressing members of the General Assembly in New York, said “there can be no higher priority at this moment than stopping the bloodshed in Syria.” “Despite the Syrian Government’s acceptance of the joint special envoy’s plan of initial proposals to resolve the crisis, the violence and assaults in civilian areas have not stopped,” Ban said. “The situation on the ground continues to deteriorate” and 1 million Syrians need humanitarian aid. “I appeal to President Assad, his government and all concerned to show vision and leadership, and to do what is right for the Syrian people,” Ban said. “I urge the opposition to be ready to cease all violence as well, as Mr. Annan’s plan Annan, who addressed the General Assembly by videoconference, cited “alarming levels” of casualties even as the Syrian government has informed him of a partial withdrawal from areas of Idlib, Daraa and Zabadani. The Syrian government must do more to meet its commitments to a March 25 agreement in order to establish conditions for a “Syrian-led political transition” to democracy, he said. “Military operations in civilian population centers have not A group of UN officials, led by a Norwegian major general, arrived in Damascus today to begin preparations for a UN cease- fire monitoring force if the Syrian government complies, Annan “We must silence the tanks, helicopters, mortars, guns, and stop all other forms of violence too -- sexual abuse, torture, executions, abductions, destruction of homes, forced displacement, and other abuses including on children,” he said. Annan said he has spoken with elements of the Syrian opposition, who have agreed to abide by a cease-fire and other provisions “once the Syrian government has demonstrably fulfilled its commitments regarding use of heavy weapons and U.K. Foreign Secretary William Hague said the Security Council made clear in its statement that it won’t accept more “broken promises” from Syria’s government about ending its crackdown on the opposition. “Today the Security Council has unanimously demanded that the Syrian regime meet its commitment to pull back troops by April 10 and end the violence, further backing Kofi Annan and his six-point plan” Hague said in an e-mailed statement. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov discussed the conflict in Syria with Annan in a telephone call today, urging the country’s opposition groups to “undertake concrete measures” to contribute to peace efforts, according to a statement published on the ministry’s website.
